articles.title: About this site
articles.description: This website will explore many different relationships between mortality rate of babies/toddlers and various variables
articles.contents:
About me
My name is Soham Gunturu and I am a rising junior in
New Albany, Ohio. I love basketball and taekwondo, and I am involved
with many different clubs at my school such as science olympiad, JSA,
and others! Please feel free to contact me at 614-477-4024 or
gunturu.soham@gmail.com. ### Github Repository https://github.com/SohamGunturu/final-project ### David
Kane Website Link https://bootcamp.davidkane.info/

articles.title: What factors affect mortalities in children
articles.description: This website will explore many different relationships between mortality rate of babies/toddlers and various variables
articles.contents:
Introdcution
Many kids throughout the world never make it past the hospital due to
various complications, illnesses, and other factors. How can we prevent
this? What type of area is this common in? Is this problem being
addressed? These are the questions we hope to answer in this analysis.
This graph will examine how the mortality rate of children under five
changes as time progresses.



The graph shows an inverse relationship. This makes sense because as
we become more modern, so does our technology and medical services. With
better medical services, we are able to save more children from death.
This graph will examine how the mortality rate of children under five
changes in different countries. The US has a GDP of $19.485 trillion,
China has a GDP of $12.238 trillion, Brazil has a GDP of $2.054
trillion, Mexico has a GDP of $1.151 trillion, Peru has a GDP of $211
billion.



The following graph provides evidence that on average, countries with
higher GDPs have lower death counts and vice versa. This graph will
examine how the mortality rate of children under five changes in
different socioeconomic classes.



As income increases, death count decreases. This makes sense because
higher income families can afford better care for their children.
Conclusion
From these graphs we can notice three trends: 1. The death count
decreases as time goes on 2. More developed countries have a lower death
count 3. Higher income families have, on average, a lower death
count
The trends in 2 and 3 are troubling. The people in need in these
areas are not receiving any. This is a problem that affects the future
heavily, and it needs to be brought to attention. These groups need to
have the resources in order to be able to afford medical services for
their children.

articles.title: Sources
articles.description: A new article created using the Distill format.
articles.contents:
This will describe what sources were used in this analysis
URL: https://databank.worldbank.org/reports.aspx?source=2&series=SH.DYN.MORT&country=#
What dataset was used
and how was it used
databank.worldbank.org I used the databank.worldbank
website to access my data set. My data set examines the number of deaths
for children under 5 per 1000 lives births in different countries,
income statuses, and regions. I used the data to study 3 different
trends: 1. Death count vs. Year 2. Death count vs. Country 3. Death
count vs. Socioeconomic Class
